If you need to talk with us, we'll re-direct your call to someone who can help you. Introduction PAYE stands for ‘pay as you earn’. PAYE means the combined income tax and ACC earners' levy, unless otherwise stated. Employers must deduct PAYE from the earnings of people who work for them and pay it to us. The tax tables tell you how to work out the amount of PAYE to deduct (includes ACC earners’ levy unless otherwise stated) and covers all the different rates you may need to use. Besides PAYE, there are other amounts you may have to deduct from your employees’ pay – these include student loan repayments, KiwiSaver and child support deductions. Note child support deduction amounts are not included in this booklet. You can also use our PAYE deductions from salary or wages calculator to work out the PAYE on an employee's gross wages. Or, if you've paid an amount to an employee, the calculator will work out how much PAYE you'll have to pay to us on the amount paid. Go to ird.govt.nz/PAYEcalculator Changes to note From 31 July 2024: •Income thresholds have been changed affecting the amount of PAYE and independent earner tax credit (IETC). From 1 April 2024: •The Student Loan repayment threshold increased to $24,128 •The ACC earners’ levy increased to $1.60 per $100 (1.60%). Levies are deducted on earnings up to a maximum of $142,283 and the total maximum levy payable is $2,276.52. Employer's guide - IR335 Our Employer's guide - IR335 will help meet your employer obligations. It explains how to deduct PAYE, child support, student loan and KiwiSaver deductions and how to forward these payments to us. It also has further information on the changes. FOUR-WEEKLY AND MONTHLY PAYE DEDUCTION TABLES 4 Part 1 – General Employer responsibilities All employers must register with us and have an IRD number. If you’re not already registered, you can do this in myIR or by completing an Employer registration - IR334 form. Employers must deduct PAYE from all remuneration paid to employees. PAYE, plus any student loan repayment deductions, child support payments and any ESCT (employer superannuation contribution tax), must be paid to us by the due date. •If your gross annual PAYE and ESCT is less than $500,000 you need to pay deductions monthly, by the 20th of the following month. You can choose to pay more often. •If your gross annual PAYE and ESCT is more than $500,000, deductions must be paid to us 2 times each month. Deductions for wages paid between 1st and 15th of the month are due by the 20th of the same month. Deductions for wages paid between 16th and the end of the month are due by the 5th of the following month except for December, these are not due until 15 January. For more information of when to pay go to ird.govt.nz/paying-deductions You must file an Employment information return every time you pay your employees. The filing date is based on your employees pay date (within 2 days if you file electronically, or 10 days for paper returns). Employment information includes details of deductions made from employees' pay, the pay day and pay period. If your total gross annual PAYE (including ESCT) deducted is $50,000 or more, you must file employment information electronically. For more information on electronic filing visit our website ird.govt.nz/payday-filing. Declarations and tax codes All new employees must complete a Tax code declaration - IR330 when they start working for you. If an employee wants to change their tax code, they must complete a new IR330. The notes on the form will help them, to work out the right tax code to use. All new contractors must complete a Tax rate notification for contractors - IR330C when they start work for you. If a contractor wants to change their rate of tax, they must complete a new IR330C showing the rate they want. You must keep all completed IR330 and IR330C forms for 7 years after the last wages payment is made to the employee. Tailored tax codes An employee may give you a tailored tax code certificate. This shows a particular rate you must use for their PAYE. This rate is not included in these tables. The rate shown will include ACC earners' levy, unless the income is not liable. Note Companies or contractors carrying out contracts in the agricultural, horticultural or viticultural industries, or contracted under a labour-hire arrangement may hold a tailored tax code certificate. For more information on the certificates see our Employer's guide - IR335. Independent earner tax credit (IETC) The IETC is a tax credit for individuals who are New Zealand tax residents, and whose annual income is between $24,000 and $70,000. The tax codes are: •ME (employes who do not have a student loan) •ME SL (employees with a student loan) To use this tax code your employee: •or partner must not be entitled to Working for Families •or partner must not receive an overseas equivalent of Working for Families •must not receive a main benefit, NZ super, Veteran’s pension or an overseas equivalent. Employees need to select the ME or ME SL on the Tax code declaration - IR330. If they’re not sure if they qualify for IETC, they can continue to use the M or M SL tax code and we will calculate their entitlement in their income tax assessment at the end of the tax year instead. ACC earners' levy All employees must pay an ACC earners' levy to cover the cost of non-work-related injuries. We collect this on behalf of the ACC. The earners' levy deduction is $1.60 GST-inclusive per $100 of earnings. The ACC earners’ levy is already included in the PAYE amount, so you do not have to do any extra calculations. ACC maximum earnings The maximum earnings on which the earners' levy deduction is payable is $142,283. For the tax code M, the earners' levy is not deducted: •in the 4-weekly table on 4-weekly salary or wages greater than $10,944 •in the monthly table on monthly salary or wages greater than $11,856. 5 FOUR-WEEKLY AND MONTHLY PAYE DEDUCTION TABLES The maximum is not applied to PAYE on: •regular secondary income •casual agricultural employee payments •election day workers' earnings •earnings on which the non-notified rate is used. People or entities receiving schedular payments are responsible for paying their own ACC levies. These tables already have the earners' levy built into them. If an employee’s pay is more than the amounts shown in the tables, use the examples at the end of each section to work out how to calculate the PAYE. Student loan repayments Employers are required to deduct student loan repayments through the PAYE system, at the standard deduction rate, for employees using a SL tax code of M SL, ME SL, SB SL, S SL, SH SL, ST SL or SA SL. Employees with a student loan who only have 1 main job should use the M SL or ME SL code. This code includes student loan repayments at the standard deduction rate of 12% for every dollar earned over the pay period repayment threshold of $464 per week. For employees using SB SL, S SL, SH SL, ST SL or SA SL codes, the tables deduct student loan repayments at 12% for every dollar earned. You’ll also need to deduct student loan repayments from any redundancy or lump sum payments. There are penalties for failure to deduct or account for student loan repayments. Do not deduct student loan repayments for casual agricultural employees, election day workers, people on schedular payments or people on the non-notified rate. For more information on how to account for student loan repayments go to ird.govt.nz/ employers or see our Employer's guide - IR335. Note An employee may give you a: •Student loan special deduction rate certificate requesting student loan repayments be made at a different rate - calculate deductions at the rate shown. •Student loan repayment deduction exemption certificate requesting no deductions be made. Student loan extra deductions Your employees may ask you to make extra deductions to pay off their loan faster or we may ask you to make compulsory extra deductions to catch up on an underpayment. These deductions are in addition to the amount you normally deduct using the student loan repayment code they've given you. You must show extra deductions separately on your employment information return as either: 1. SLBOR – employee requests voluntary extra deductions 2. SLCIR – we request you to make compulsory extra deductions. Schedular payments Contractors working for you have the option of choosing their own tax rate (provided it is not under 10%). If they do not choose a rate on their Tax rate notification for contractors - IR330C deduct tax from the gross payment at the standard rate for their activity. Find the tax rate for their activity on page 16, and page 3 of the IR330C. The following rules apply to non-resident contractors and entertainers, and contractors on a temporary entry class visa. •Non-resident contractors and people on temporary entry class visas cannot choose below 15%. •Non-resident entertainers and sports people visiting New Zealand cannot choose their own tax rate. •Non-resident contracting companies have a non-notified rate of 20%. If the contractor chooses a rate we believe is incorrect we may send you a letter advising of the rate to use for their tax deductions. Note If the person or entity working for you is GST registered show the GST exclusive amount on the employment information. For more information see our Employer’s guide - IR335. FOUR-WEEKLY AND MONTHLY PAYE DEDUCTION TABLES 6 KiwiSaver As an employer, you need to give employees information about KiwiSaver, deduct KiwiSaver contributions from their pay and contribute a percentage of your employees' salary and wages as employer contributions. You’re required to enrol all new eligible employees for KiwiSaver unless an exemption applies. Employee deductions All eligible salary and wage earners must complete a KiwiSaver deduction form - KS2 when they start working for you. You must keep this form for 7 years, along with other wage records. This form includes the rate your employee has elected to have KiwiSaver deductions made from their pay, either 3%, 4%, 6%, 8% or 10%. If automatically enrolled employees do not give you a KS2 form, the default deduction rate is 3% of their gross salary or wages. Employer's superannuation cash contribution (employer contribution) An employer contribution is a monetary amount paid to a superannuation fund, by an employer, for the benefit of their employees'. It does not include an employee deduction. You must contribute a minimum of 3% of your employees' gross salary or wages. All employer contributions paid to a superannuation fund, including KiwiSaver schemes and complying funds, for the benefit of an employee are liable for ESCT (employer's superannuation contribution tax). The exception to this is if the employee and employer have agreed to treat some or all of the employer contribution as salary or wages under the PAYE rules. The PAYE tables include compulsory employer contributions (CECs) and ESCT, under the column Net CEC and ESCT. You need to show the net employer contributions and ESCT for each employee separately on your employer information return. How to tax employer contributions There are 2 options for calculating and withholding tax on employer contributions: •If you and your employee agree, the amount of employer contribution can be treated as the employee's salary or wages and PAYE must be deducted. •In all other cases, ESCT must be withheld. ESCT is calculated at a rate based on the employee's total annual salary or wages plus gross employer contributions for the previous tax year (1 April to 31 March). When employees have not worked for you for the full previous tax year, the rate is based on your estimate of the employee's total salary or wages plus gross employer contributions they will receive in the tax year the ESCT is being calculated for. Salary or wage income for year ended 31 March 2024\* ESCT from 1 April 2024 $0 – $16,80010.5% $16,801 – $57,60017.5% $57,601 – $84,00030.0% $84,001 – $216,00033.0% $216,001 upwards39.0% \* This includes gross superannuation employer contributions. Note Employers paying into a defined benefit fund can choose to apply ESCT at the flat rate of 39%. ESCT is calculated on whole dollars and is deducted from the gross employer contribution. Example Employee gross earnings of $1,792.00 and an ESCT rate of 17.5% Gross employer contribution (3%) $53.76 ESCT is applied $53.00 $53.00 × 17.5% = $9.27 ESCT Minus the ESCT from the gross employer contribution $53.76 − $9.27 = $44.49 Net CEC 7 FOUR-WEEKLY AND MONTHLY PAYE DEDUCTION TABLES Calculating grossed-up employer contributions In some cases you may have an employment agreement to contribute a set percentage of an employees' salary. It may be necessary to gross up the employer contribution, so the employee receives their full entitlement. Example The employer has an agreement with his employee to pay a net amount of $1,000.00 to the employee's superannuation fund and the employee has an ESCT rate of 30%. Using the formula: ESCT = a × b (1−a) a = ESCT rate b = employer contribution 0.30 × 1,000 = $428.57 (1 − 0.30) Gross employer contribution $1,428.57 For more information about ESCT see your Employer's guide - IR335 or for information about KiwiSaver go to: ird.govt.nz/kiwisaver Running totals Running totals are your gross earnings and PAYE deductions paid since 1 April. You can check your running totals for the current and the immediately preceding tax year by calling our 0800 self-service - see page 3. Late payment We may charge you a late payment penalty if you miss a payment or it's late. We'll also charge you interest if you do not make your tax payment by the due date. If you cannot pay your tax by the due date, please call us. We'll look at your payment options, which may include an instalment arrangement, depending on your circumstances. For more information about penalties go to ird.govt.nz/penalties For more help See our guide Penalties and interest - IR240. FOUR-WEEKLY AND MONTHLY PAYE DEDUCTION TABLES 8 Part 2 – Using these tables The PAYE tables shown in this booklet are for four-weekly and monthly pay periods and secondary employment. Four-weekly and monthly Use these tables to calculate how much PAYE to deduct from your employees’ main job earnings for 4-weekly and monthly pay periods. To calculate PAYE for pay periods other than 4-weekly or monthly, see page 9. Income thresholds PAYE rate $0 – $15,60012.1% $15,601 – $53,50019.1% $53,501 – $78,10031.6% $78,101 – $142,28334.6% $142,284 - $180,00033.0% $180,001 upwards39.0% Note The maximum income liable for the earners' levy is $142,283. Income between $142,283 and $180,000 is taxed at 33%, and income of $180,001 and over is taxed at 39%. Independent earner tax credit (IETC) IETC for employees using ME or ME SL tax code reduces their PAYE by $10 per week for income between $24,000 and $66,000 For each extra dollar earned over $66,000, IETC reduces by $0.13, reaching a nil entitlement at $70,000. This tax credit is built into the PAYE tables, so you do not need to do any additional calculations. Student loan repayments Employees using a ME SL or M SL tax code have the student loan standard deduction rate of 12% for every dollar earned over the pay period repayment threshold (annual earnings over $24,128). Student loan pay period repayment thresholds: •Weekly $464.00  Fortnightly $928.00 •4-weekly $1,856.00  Monthly $2,010.66 Secondary employment The secondary tables apply to employees who already have a main job source of income (for example a regular job, taxable pension, main benefit or student allowance) and take on a second job. The PAYE deducted from secondary employment income depends on the secondary tax code selected on their Tax code declaration - IR330. Employees with a student loan use a tax code ending in SL. Income thresholds Tax codes (no student loan) PAYE rateStudent loan tax codes PAYE rate + Student loan deduction $0 – $15,600 SB 12.1%SB SL24.1% $15,601 – $53,500 S19.1%S SL31.1% $53,501 – $78,100SH31.6%SH SL43.6% $78,101 – $180,000 ST 34.6%ST SL 46.6% $180,001 upwards SA 40.6%SA SL52.6% How to calculate employee PAYE deductions •Basic 4-weekly or monthly pay •Add overtime, any regular bonus, shift allowance, value of board and lodging, and any other taxable allowance. Overtime is treated as ordinary pay. Add it into the salary or wages you've paid for that pay period then deduct PAYE in the usual way. It does not matter if the overtime was worked in another pay period. This is the total employee earnings for PAYE to be calculated on. Example Example for tax code M SL Basic 4-weekly pay of $1,658 and overtime of $206.40 Basic 4-weekly pay $1,658.00 Add overtime $ 206.40 Earnings for PAYE (and other deductions) $1,864.40 9 FOUR-WEEKLY AND MONTHLY PAYE DEDUCTION TABLES Main job income (M, M SL, ME or ME SL) •Look up the employee’s total earnings in the weekly or fortnightly table. If the exact amount is not shown, use the nearest lower figure. \* •Deduct the amount of PAYE, student loan repayments and/or KiwiSaver deductions shown in line with the employee's earnings for the employee's tax code (M SL in our example). In the example the total earnings are $1,864.40. The nearest lower figure in the table is $1,864. Find the PAYE, student loan and KiwiSaver deductions in the columns opposite this amount. Note \* Calculations may differ slightly from the results produced by our online PAYE/KiwiSaver calculator Add any non-taxable allowances after the PAYE, student loan repayments and KiwiSaver employee contributions have been deducted. The take-home pay is: •employee’s total earnings for PAYE •less PAYE •less student loan repayment •less KiwiSaver employee deductions •plus any non-taxable allowance. Example M SL example continued Based on our M SL example: Employee’s total earnings for PAYE $1,864.40 Less PAYE $ 272.00 Less student loan $ 0.96 $1,591.44 Plus non-taxable meal allowance $ 20.50 Take-home pay is $1,611.94 Other than 4-weekly or monthly pay periods Daily or casual basis For employees who work on a daily or casual basis, there are 2 ways to calculate how much PAYE to deduct. Either: •add up the employee's earnings for each week, and use the 4-weekly table to calculate the PAYE on those earnings, or •work out the PAYE progressively using the weekly tax tables (IR340) for each day the employee is paid, so as weekly income increases, the PAYE you must deduct increases. Example – PAYE calculated progressively An employee works on Monday, Tuesday and Friday of the same week, earning $125 each day. The employee is paid on each day worked and is on the M tax code. Earnings based on M tax code Earnings for week PAYE on w e ek ’s earnings to date PAYE already deducted for week PAYE to deduct from day’s pay Amount paid to employee each day Monday $125 $125.0015.12-15.12109.88 Tuesday $125 $250.0030.2515.1215.13109.87 Friday $125 $375.0050.6230.2520.37104.62 3-weekly pay periods If you pay wages 3-weekly, you'll need the July 2024 weekly and fortnightly PAYE deduction tables - IR340. If you pay wages 3 weekly calculate the PAYE as follows: •Divide the 3-weekly wage by 3 to get the weekly income •Use the weekly tables to find the PAYE (IR340) •Multiply the weekly PAYE by 3. This is the 3-weekly PAYE deduction. FOUR-WEEKLY AND MONTHLY PAYE DEDUCTION TABLES 10 Half-monthly pay periods Calculate the PAYE using these tables (IR341) as follows: •Double the taxable earnings for the half-monthly period •Calculate PAYE on this amount using the monthly table •Divide the monthly PAYE deduction by 2. This is the PAYE to deduct for the half month. Change of pay period If you change a pay period but not the day of the week you pay wages or salaries, use the PAYE table that covers the new pay period. Example River Industries changed its pay period from 4-weekly to fortnightly. The employees are still paid on a Friday. The fortnightly PAYE table is used from the first payday of the new fortnightly pay period. Changed payday If the pay day changes, there is a broken period between the end of the old period and the beginning of the new period. Calculate the PAYE as follows: •Increase the taxable earnings proportionately for the broken period to show the amount payable for the whole of the original pay period •Calculate the PAYE on the increased figure using the table for the old pay period •Reduce the PAYE proportionately to match the actual earnings for the broken period. Example A 4-weekly pay period Monday to Friday (20 working days) changes to fortnightly (10 working days) period. The fortnight ends on Wednesday. The broken period is from Monday to the following Wednesday - 8 days out of the old 20-day period. An employee's taxable earnings for the 8 days is $600. Increase $600 to 4-weekly pay (20 ÷ 8 × $600) $ 1,500.00 PAYE on $1,500 (using 4-weekly table) $ 202.48 PAYE deduction for the broken period (8 ÷ 20 × $202.48) $ 80.99 Less than a full pay period If an employee starts working for you, finishes working for you, or loses any pay during a period, treat the earnings as if they were earned over the full pay period. Example Wood Industries Ltd has a monthly pay period. A new employee starts work halfway through the month. The PAYE for the new employee's first pay is calculated using the monthly table, in the same way as a full month's pay. Non-notified rate If an employee does not give you a Tax code declaration - IR330, or has not completed the required details, you must use the non-notified PAYE rate. A completed IR330 must show the employee's: •IRD number •name •tax code. The non-notified PAYE rate is 46.6% (includes earners' levy). If a contractor does not give you a completed Tax rate notification for contractors - IR330C, you must use the non-notified tax rate. A completed IR330C must show the contractor's name and IRD number. The non-notified rate for contractors is 45%, except for non-resident contracting companies where the rate is 20%. How to calculate PAYE at the non-notified rate for salary and wages •Take the employee’s gross earnings. •Add the value of taxable allowances, if any. •This is the total earnings for PAYE. •Using whole dollars, work out PAYE, at 46.6% (includes earners' levy) Example Non-notified rate Weekly pay $1,585.75 Tax on whole dollars $1,585.00 × 46.6% PAYE to be deducted $ 738.61 11 FOUR-WEEKLY AND MONTHLY PAYE DEDUCTION TABLES Holiday Pay Include holiday pay and statutory holiday pay as earnings in the period you pay them. PAYE for holiday pay can be calculated either as standard salary or wages, or as an extra pay. To calculate tax on your employee's holiday pay, decide whether it should be calculated as an extra pay or not: Holiday pay treated as standard salary or wages If the holiday pay is included in the employee's regular pay at 8% of the employee's gross pay or linked to the workdays within the pay period (such as not working but being paid for a public holiday or annual leave) then it’s treated as salary or wages for the pay period. Holiday pay treated as an extra pay Holiday pay paid in addition to the regular pay for the pay period is treated as an extra pay. These are payments that are not normally paid in the pay period, such as when accumulated leave is paid out at the end of employment. Holiday pay paid in advance If you pay your employee annual leave in a lump sum before the leave is taken, you can choose to calculate tax as a lump sum either as •an extra pay or •if the lump sum were paid to the employee in their regular pay cycle over the pay periods their holiday covers (the alternative approach). This calculation also applies to lump sum payments of salary/wages in advance. Calculate PAYE using the alternative approach by: •apportion the lump sum payment across the pay periods the payment relates to •calculate PAYE on each apportioned amount as if they were the only payments made to the employee in each pay period •add PAYE amounts together and deduct the amount from the lump sum payment. A more complex PAYE calculation is needed when the whole pay period is not taken as annual leave and the annual leave was taxed using the alternative approach. This can happen when an employee takes leave for part of a pay period and works as normal for the remainder. PAYE is calculated by: •add the amount of the holiday pay and the regular salary/wages together for the pay period •calculating the amount of PAYE that is required to be withheld from the combined amount as if it were a single payment, this is the total PAYE payable for the pay period •subtract the PAYE deducted from the holiday pay apportioned to the pay period from the amount of PAYE calculated in the previous step. This is the amount of PAYE to be deducted from the payment of salary/wages. Example Kim is taking 3 weeks annual leave and asks her employer Dan to pay the holiday pay in a lump sum before the leave is taken. Kim is paid fortnightly and uses the M tax code •Regular fortnightly pay is $1,492.00 •3 weeks holiday pay is $2,238.00. The holiday pay covers 3 weeks across 2 fortnightly pay periods. Kim is back at work in the last week of the 2nd fortnight. Dan apportions the holiday pay across Kim’s pay periods and calculates the PAYE using the alternate approach: Holiday pay PAYE 1 st fortnight $1,492.00 $242.96 2 nd fortnight $ 746.00 $100.48 Totals $2,238.00 $343.44 Dan calculates the PAYE he needs to deduct for the week Kim worked in the 2nd fortnight: Amount PAYE 1 week's holiday pay $ 746.00 1 week's normal pay $ 746.00 Totals $1,492.00 $ 242.96 Less PAYE deducted on week 3 of holiday pay $ 100.48 Total PAYE for the week Kim worked $ 142.48 Dan deducts $142.48 from Kim’s pay for the week she worked after her annual leave. Note If your employee is a KiwiSaver member or has a student loan, these deductions and repayments are calculated on the whole lump sum, even if you choose to calculate PAYE using the alternative approach. For more information about holiday pay go to ird.govt.nz/holiday-pay FOUR-WEEKLY AND MONTHLY PAYE DEDUCTION TABLES 12 Lump sum payments Lump sum payments for main job employment Lump sum payments include annual or special bonuses, retiring or redundancy payments, payments for accepting restrictive covenants, exit inducement payments, gratuities or back pay. These are also called extra pays. Overtime or any regular payments are not lump sum payments. You can choose to calculate PAYE on a lump sum payment paid in advance either: •as an extra pay, or •as if the lump sum were paid to the employee in their regular pay cycle over the pay periods the salary/wage would ordinarily apply to (the alternative approach). Refer to page 11 for more details on this calculation. If an employee is on the non-notified rate (ND tax code) or they are a non-resident seasonal worker on the NSW tax code (see page 15), PAYE calculated on any lump sum extra pays is based on the flat rate that applies to each tax code: •10.5% for the NSW code (plus ACC earners levy, if applicable), •45.0% for the ND tax code (plus ACC earners levy, if applicable). How to calculate PAYE on lump sum payments •Work out the employee’s annualised income\* •Add annualised income to the lump sum payment. •This is the total combined amount for calculating PAYE. \* Annualised income is calculated by adding up the PAYE income payments for the 4 weeks ending on the date of the lump sum payment, whether this is the normal pay cycle or not, and multiplying by 13. The lump sum amount is not included in this total. Note The income thresholds tables in this section should be used for any lump sum payments, including redundancy and retiring allowances for main and secondary job employees, up to 31 March 2025. The new threshold rates do not apply until after this date. Use the following information to work out the PAYE rate to use: Lump sum payment + annualised income for previous 4 weeks PAYE rate $0 – $14,000 12.1% $14,001 – $48,00019.1% $48,001 – $70,00031.6% $70,001 – $142,283\*34.6% $142,284 - $180,00033.0% $180,001 upwards\*\*39.0% \* The maximum amount of earnings for ACC earners’ levy for the year ending 31 March 2025. \*\* Use 39% if the employee asks to you use this rate. Note •ACC earners’ levy does not apply to retiring or redundancy payments. These should have PAYE applied at 10.5%, 17.5%, 30%, 33% or 39% according to annualised income. •If the lump sum has PAYE using the lowest rate (12.1%), tick the box on your Employment information return - IR348 to show this. Example Gary is paying a bonus payment of $400 to an employee. Total employee’s earnings for the last 4 weeks $2,500: Annualised income (13 × $2,500) $ 32,500 Add the bonus payment $ 400 To t a l $ 32,900 In this example, the total is between $14,001 and $48,000 so the PAYE rate applied to the bonus payment is 19.1%. Student loan repayments on lump sum payments If the employee uses a tax code with SL, for example M SL or ME SL, you'll also have to deduct student loan repayments. Add any gross salary or wage payments for the same period to the gross lump sum amount and deduct the pay period threshold. The remaining amount will have the student loan repayments made at the standard deduction rate of 12%. KiwiSaver contributions on lump sum payments If the employee is a KiwiSaver member, you’ll need to deduct contributions from the lump sum payment. 13 FOUR-WEEKLY AND MONTHLY PAYE DEDUCTION TABLES Lump sum payments for secondary employment The calculation for lump sum payments for secondary employment uses the minimum income the employee expects to receive from their main job employment, based on the secondary tax code they have selected. The calculation for PAYE on an extra pay for employees using a secondary tax code is: •the amount of the extra pay •plus annualised income\* •plus the low threshold amount, (based on the secondary tax code used - see the following table). The total is the annual income estimate. \* Annualised income is calculated by adding up the PAYE income payments for the 4 weeks ending on the date of the extra pay, whether this is the normal pay cycle or not, and multiplying by 13. The amount of the extra pay is not included in this total. Income thresholds Tax codes (no student loan) PAYE rate Student loan tax codes PAYE rate + Student loan deduction Low threshold $0$14,000SB12.1%SB SL24.1% $14,001$48,000S19.1%S SL31.1% $48,001$70,000SH31.6%SH SL43.6% $70,001$142,283\*ST34.6%ST SL46.6% $142,284$180,000ST33.0%ST SL45.0% $180,001upwardsSA39.0%SA SL51.0% •If the annual income estimate is less than $142,283\*, the amount of PAYE is calculated on the full extra pay using the rate shown. •If the annualised income plus the low threshold amount is more than $142,283, the total extra pay is not liable for earners’ levy. The PAYE rate is 33% for income up to $180,000, and 39% for income of $180,001 and over. •If the annualised income plus the low threshold is $142,283 or less, but the annual income estimate is more than $142,283: –the amount of PAYE applied to the extra pay amount below the threshold is calculated at 34.6% –the extra pay amount above $142,283 has no ACC earner levy, PAYE is calculated at 33.0%. Example Jane has a secondary job and uses the ST tax code. Jane’s secondary employer wants to pay her a bonus of $30,000. In the last 4 weeks Jane has earned $3,298 from her second job. Jane’s employer works out the amount of PAYE on her bonus: Annualised income ($3,298 × 13) $ 42,874 plus low threshold (ST tax code) $ 70,001 $112,875 plus extra pay $ 30,000 Total amount $142,875 The annualised income plus the low threshold amount is below $142,283. But when the lump sum is added, the annualised income of $147,875, it’s more than $142,283. The earners’ levy only applies to $29,408 of the extra pay (PAYE rate is 34.6%). The remaining $592 does not have any earners’ levy applied and is the PAYE rate is 33.0%. Example In this example PAYE is calculated on the full bonus, and then the excess earners’ levy is deducted. $30,000 × 34.6% = $10,380 Annual income estimate − ACC threshold = lump sum amount not liable for earners’ levy $142,875 − $142,283\* = $592.00 $592 × 1.6% = $9.47 $10,380 − $9.47 = the amount of PAYE applied to the lump sum $10,370.53 \*The maximum amount of earnings for ACC earners’ levy for the year ending 31 March 2025. FOUR-WEEKLY AND MONTHLY PAYE DEDUCTION TABLES 14 Redundancy payments and retiring allowances for main job employees Redundancy payments and retiring allowances do not have earners' levy added to the calculation. For main job employment the tax rate is 1 of the following: Main job employment Income thresholdsPAYE rate $0 – $14,00010.5% $14,001 – $48,00017.5% $48,001 – $70,00030.0% $70,001 – 180,00033.0% $180,001 upwards39.0% Example A redundancy payment of $10,200 is paid to an employee. Their total wages for the last 4 weeks are $2,800. The calculation is: Annualised income (13 × $2,800) $ 36,400 Add the redundancy payment $ 10,200 To t a l $ 46,600 In this example, the income level is more than $14,000 but less than $48,001 so the tax rate applied to the redundancy payment is 17.5% Student loan repayments on redundancy and retirement payments For tax codes M SL and ME SL you need to add together any gross salary or wage payments for the same period to the gross lump sum amount and deduct the pay period threshold. Calculate the student loan repayments on the remaining amount at the standard deduction rate of 12%. Example Student loan deduction – 4 weekly pay period Student loan deduction on redundancy payment of $10,200 and the 4 weeks wages of $2,800 in the same period using pay period threshold $1,856: PAYE on $10,200 x 17.5%\* $ 1,785.00 Student loan repayment ($2,800 + $10,200 – $1,856 = $11,144) x 12% $ 1,337.28 Total deductions $ 3,122.28 \*In the example the gross annual value of the employee's income for the previous 4 weeks, plus the redundancy payment, is more than $14,000 but less than $48,001. Secondary employment The calculation for PAYE on redundancy and retirement payments for employees using a secondary tax code is: •the redundancy/retirement payment amount •plus annualised income\* •plus the minimum income threshold amount, based on the secondary tax code used (see the following table) The total is the annual income estimate. \* Annualised income is calculated by adding up the PAYE income payments for the 4 weeks ending on the date of the lump sum payment, whether this is the normal pay cycle or not, and multiplying by 13. The amount of the lump sum payment is not included in this total. Income thresholds Tax codes (no student loan) PAYE rate Student loan tax codes PAYE rate + Student loan deduction Low threshold $0$14,000SB10.5%SB SL22.5% $14,001$48,000S17.5%S SL29.5% $48,001$70,000SH30.0%SH SL42.0% $70,001$180,000ST33.0%ST SL45.0% $180,001upwardsSA39.0%ST SL51.0% Student loan repayment on redundancy payments for secondary tax codes Student loan repayments are made at 12%. Example Maria is making a redundancy payment of $11,000 to an employee using the SH SL tax code. Their total earnings for the last 4 weeks is $3,000. Annualised income (13 × $3,000) $ 39,000 Add the redundancy payment $ 11,000 Add the low income threshold amount $ 48,001 To t a l $ 98,001 In this example, the income amount of $98,001 is more than $70,000 so the tax rate applied to the redundancy payment is 45.0% (includes the student loan repayment of 12%). 15 FOUR-WEEKLY AND MONTHLY PAYE DEDUCTION TABLES Note Do not make KiwiSaver deductions from redundancy payments as these are exempt. Casual agricultural employees and election day workers Casual agricultural employees include shearers, shearing shed hands and casual agricultural workers. The flat rate of PAYE for casual agricultural employees and election day workers is 19.1%. (includes ACC earners' levy). Calculate the PAYE as follows: • Total earnings •Add the value of taxable allowances if any This is the total employee earnings for PAYE to be calculated on. Work out PAYE at the rate of 19.1 % on whole dollars only. Example Earnings as a shearing shed hand $135.00 PAYE to be deducted at 19.1% $ 25.78 Non-resident seasonal workers Non-resident seasonal workers are either recognised seasonal workers or foreign fishing workers. Recognised seasonal workers must be employed by recognised seasonal employers who are approved by the Ministry of Business, Innovation and Employment. They are generally employed in the horticulture and viticulture industries. Foreign fishing workers holding a work visa as foreign crew of a vessel fishing New Zealand waters are non-residents for New Zealand tax purposes. However, they must pay tax on their New Zealand income (income paid to them while fishing in New Zealand waters). These workers are taxed through the PAYE system using the NSW tax code and at a flat rate of 12.1%. (includes ACC earners’ levy). Example Earnings (use whole dollars only) $ 250.00 PAYE to be deducted at 12.1% $ 30.25 You may also have to make deductions for child support payments. Non-resident seasonal workers do not have student loan repayments and they are not eligible to join KiwiSaver. Secondary Earnings: Tax Code SB, S, SH, ST, SA – Earnings $19,204 to $19,228 345 FOUR-WEEKLY AND MONTHLY PAYE DEDUCTION TABLES Tax codes SB, S, SH, ST and SA How to calculate PAYE on secondary earnings over $19,228 •Take gross earnings •Add overtime, any regular bonus, shift allowance, value of board and lodging and any other taxable allowances, if applicable.
